Tensor derivative (continuum mechanics)

The derivatives of scalars, vectors, and second-order tensors with respect to second-order tensors are of considerable use in continuum mechanics. These derivatives are used in the theories of nonlinear elasticity and plasticity, particularly in the design of algorithms for numerical simulations.1

The directional derivative provides a systematic way of finding these derivatives.2

Derivatives with respect to vectors and second-order tensors

The definitions of directional derivatives for various situations are given below. It is assumed that the functions are sufficiently smooth that derivatives can be taken.

Derivatives of scalar valued functions of vectors

Let f(v) be a real valued function of the vector v. Then the derivative of f(v) with respect to v (or at v) in the direction u is the vector defined as

‚àÇ f ‚àÇ ùêØ ‚ãÖ ùêÆ = D f ( ùêØ ) [ ùêÆ ] = [ d d Œ± f ( ùêØ + Œ± ùêÆ ) ] Œ± = 0 normal-‚ãÖ f ùêØ ùêÆ D f ùêØ delimited-[] ùêÆ subscript delimited-[] d d Œ± f ùêØ Œ± ùêÆ Œ± 0 \frac{\partial f}{\partial\mathbf{v}}\cdot\mathbf{u}=Df(\mathbf{v})[\mathbf{u}% ]=\left[\frac{d}{d\alpha}~{}f(\mathbf{v}+\alpha~{}\mathbf{u})\right]_{\alpha=0}

for all vectors u.

Properties:

1) If f ( ùêØ ) = f 1 ( ùêØ ) + f 2 ( ùêØ ) f ùêØ subscript f 1 ùêØ subscript f 2 ùêØ f(\mathbf{v})=f_{1}(\mathbf{v})+f_{2}(\mathbf{v}) then ‚àÇ f ‚àÇ ùêØ ‚ãÖ ùêÆ = ( ‚àÇ f 1 ‚àÇ ùêØ + ‚àÇ f 2 ‚àÇ ùêØ ) ‚ãÖ ùêÆ normal-‚ãÖ f ùêØ ùêÆ normal-‚ãÖ subscript f 1 ùêØ subscript f 2 ùêØ ùêÆ \frac{\partial f}{\partial\mathbf{v}}\cdot\mathbf{u}=\left(\frac{\partial f_{1% }}{\partial\mathbf{v}}+\frac{\partial f_{2}}{\partial\mathbf{v}}\right)\cdot% \mathbf{u}

2) If f ( ùêØ ) = f 1 ( ùêØ ) f 2 ( ùêØ ) f ùêØ subscript f 1 ùêØ subscript f 2 ùêØ f(\mathbf{v})=f_{1}(\mathbf{v})~{}f_{2}(\mathbf{v}) then ‚àÇ f ‚àÇ ùêØ ‚ãÖ ùêÆ = ( ‚àÇ f 1 ‚àÇ ùêØ ‚ãÖ ùêÆ ) f 2 ( ùêØ ) + f 1 ( ùêØ ) ( ‚àÇ f 2 ‚àÇ ùêØ ‚ãÖ ùêÆ ) normal-‚ãÖ f ùêØ ùêÆ normal-‚ãÖ subscript f 1 ùêØ ùêÆ subscript f 2 ùêØ subscript f 1 ùêØ normal-‚ãÖ subscript f 2 ùêØ ùêÆ \frac{\partial f}{\partial\mathbf{v}}\cdot\mathbf{u}=\left(\frac{\partial f_{1% }}{\partial\mathbf{v}}\cdot\mathbf{u}\right)~{}f_{2}(\mathbf{v})+f_{1}(\mathbf% {v})~{}\left(\frac{\partial f_{2}}{\partial\mathbf{v}}\cdot\mathbf{u}\right)

3) If f ( ùêØ ) = f 1 ( f 2 ( ùêØ ) ) f ùêØ subscript f 1 subscript f 2 ùêØ f(\mathbf{v})=f_{1}(f_{2}(\mathbf{v})) then ‚àÇ f ‚àÇ ùêØ ‚ãÖ ùêÆ = ‚àÇ f 1 ‚àÇ f 2 ‚àÇ f 2 ‚àÇ ùêØ ‚ãÖ ùêÆ normal-‚ãÖ f ùêØ ùêÆ normal-‚ãÖ subscript f 1 subscript f 2 subscript f 2 ùêØ ùêÆ \frac{\partial f}{\partial\mathbf{v}}\cdot\mathbf{u}=\frac{\partial f_{1}}{% \partial f_{2}}~{}\frac{\partial f_{2}}{\partial\mathbf{v}}\cdot\mathbf{u}

Derivatives of vector valued functions of vectors

Let f(v) be a vector valued function of the vector v. Then the derivative of f(v) with respect to v (or at v) in the direction u is the ' second order tensor' defined as

‚àÇ ùêü ‚àÇ ùêØ ‚ãÖ ùêÆ = D ùêü ( ùêØ ) [ ùêÆ ] = [ d d Œ± ùêü ( ùêØ + Œ± ùêÆ ) ] Œ± = 0 normal-‚ãÖ ùêü ùêØ ùêÆ D ùêü ùêØ delimited-[] ùêÆ subscript delimited-[] d d Œ± ùêü ùêØ Œ± ùêÆ Œ± 0 \frac{\partial\mathbf{f}}{\partial\mathbf{v}}\cdot\mathbf{u}=D\mathbf{f}(% \mathbf{v})[\mathbf{u}]=\left[\frac{d}{d\alpha}~{}\mathbf{f}(\mathbf{v}+\alpha% ~{}\mathbf{u})\right]_{\alpha=0} for all vectors u.

Properties:
1) If ùêü ( ùêØ ) = ùêü 1 ( ùêØ ) + ùêü 2 ( ùêØ ) ùêü ùêØ subscript ùêü 1 ùêØ subscript ùêü 2 ùêØ \mathbf{f}(\mathbf{v})=\mathbf{f}_{1}(\mathbf{v})+\mathbf{f}_{2}(\mathbf{v}) then ‚àÇ ùêü ‚àÇ ùêØ ‚ãÖ ùêÆ = ( ‚àÇ ùêü 1 ‚àÇ ùêØ + ‚àÇ ùêü 2 ‚àÇ ùêØ ) ‚ãÖ ùêÆ normal-‚ãÖ ùêü ùêØ ùêÆ normal-‚ãÖ subscript ùêü 1 ùêØ subscript ùêü 2 ùêØ ùêÆ \frac{\partial\mathbf{f}}{\partial\mathbf{v}}\cdot\mathbf{u}=\left(\frac{% \partial\mathbf{f}_{1}}{\partial\mathbf{v}}+\frac{\partial\mathbf{f}_{2}}{% \partial\mathbf{v}}\right)\cdot\mathbf{u}
2) If ùêü ( ùêØ ) = ùêü 1 ( ùêØ ) √ó ùêü 2 ( ùêØ ) ùêü ùêØ subscript ùêü 1 ùêØ subscript ùêü 2 ùêØ \mathbf{f}(\mathbf{v})=\mathbf{f}_{1}(\mathbf{v})\times\mathbf{f}_{2}(\mathbf{% v}) then ‚àÇ ùêü ‚àÇ ùêØ ‚ãÖ ùêÆ = ( ‚àÇ ùêü 1 ‚àÇ ùêØ ‚ãÖ ùêÆ ) √ó ùêü 2 ( ùêØ ) + ùêü 1 ( ùêØ ) √ó ( ‚àÇ ùêü 2 ‚àÇ ùêØ ‚ãÖ ùêÆ ) normal-‚ãÖ ùêü ùêØ ùêÆ normal-‚ãÖ subscript ùêü 1 ùêØ ùêÆ subscript ùêü 2 ùêØ subscript ùêü 1 ùêØ normal-‚ãÖ subscript ùêü 2 ùêØ ùêÆ \frac{\partial\mathbf{f}}{\partial\mathbf{v}}\cdot\mathbf{u}=\left(\frac{% \partial\mathbf{f}_{1}}{\partial\mathbf{v}}\cdot\mathbf{u}\right)\times\mathbf% {f}_{2}(\mathbf{v})+\mathbf{f}_{1}(\mathbf{v})\times\left(\frac{\partial% \mathbf{f}_{2}}{\partial\mathbf{v}}\cdot\mathbf{u}\right)
3) If ùêü ( ùêØ ) = ùêü 1 ( ùêü 2 ( ùêØ ) ) ùêü ùêØ subscript ùêü 1 subscript ùêü 2 ùêØ \mathbf{f}(\mathbf{v})=\mathbf{f}_{1}(\mathbf{f}_{2}(\mathbf{v})) then ‚àÇ ùêü ‚àÇ ùêØ ‚ãÖ ùêÆ = ‚àÇ ùêü 1 ‚àÇ ùêü 2 ‚ãÖ ( ‚àÇ ùêü 2 ‚àÇ ùêØ ‚ãÖ ùêÆ ) normal-‚ãÖ ùêü ùêØ ùêÆ normal-‚ãÖ subscript ùêü 1 subscript ùêü 2 normal-‚ãÖ subscript ùêü 2 ùêØ ùêÆ \frac{\partial\mathbf{f}}{\partial\mathbf{v}}\cdot\mathbf{u}=\frac{\partial% \mathbf{f}_{1}}{\partial\mathbf{f}_{2}}\cdot\left(\frac{\partial\mathbf{f}_{2}% }{\partial\mathbf{v}}\cdot\mathbf{u}\right)

Derivatives of scalar valued functions of second-order tensors

Let f ( s y m b o l S ) f s y m b o l S f(symbol{S}) be a real valued function of the second order tensor s y m b o l S s y m b o l S symbol{S} . Then the derivative of f ( s y m b o l S ) f s y m b o l S f(symbol{S}) with respect to s y m b o l S s y m b o l S symbol{S} (or at s y m b o l S s y m b o l S symbol{S} ) in the direction s y m b o l T s y m b o l T symbol{T} is the ' second order tensor' defined as

‚àÇ f ‚àÇ s y m b o l S : s y m b o l T = D f ( s y m b o l S ) [ s y m b o l T ] = [ d d Œ± f ( s y m b o l S + Œ± s y m b o l T ) ] Œ± = 0 normal-: f s y m b o l S s y m b o l T D f s y m b o l S delimited-[] s y m b o l T subscript delimited-[] d d Œ± f s y m b o l S Œ± s y m b o l T Œ± 0 \frac{\partial f}{\partial symbol{S}}:symbol{T}=Df(symbol{S})[symbol{T}]=\left% [\frac{d}{d\alpha}~{}f(symbol{S}+\alpha~{}symbol{T})\right]_{\alpha=0} for all second order tensors s y m b o l T s y m b o l T symbol{T} .

Properties:
1) If f ( s y m b o l S ) = f 1 ( s y m b o l S ) + f 2 ( s y m b o l S ) f s y m b o l S subscript f 1 s y m b o l S subscript f 2 s y m b o l S f(symbol{S})=f_{1}(symbol{S})+f_{2}(symbol{S}) then ‚àÇ f ‚àÇ s y m b o l S : s y m b o l T = ( ‚àÇ f 1 ‚àÇ s y m b o l S + ‚àÇ f 2 ‚àÇ s y m b o l S ) : s y m b o l T normal-: f s y m b o l S s y m b o l T subscript f 1 s y m b o l S subscript f 2 s y m b o l S normal-: s y m b o l T \frac{\partial f}{\partial symbol{S}}:symbol{T}=\left(\frac{\partial f_{1}}{% \partial symbol{S}}+\frac{\partial f_{2}}{\partial symbol{S}}\right):symbol{T}
2) If f ( s y m b o l S ) = f 1 ( s y m b o l S ) f 2 ( s y m b o l S ) f s y m b o l S subscript f 1 s y m b o l S subscript f 2 s y m b o l S f(symbol{S})=f_{1}(symbol{S})~{}f_{2}(symbol{S}) then ‚àÇ f ‚àÇ s y m b o l S : s y m b o l T = ( ‚àÇ f 1 ‚àÇ s y m b o l S : s y m b o l T ) f 2 ( s y m b o l S ) + f 1 ( s y m b o l S ) ( ‚àÇ f 2 ‚àÇ s y m b o l S : s y m b o l T ) fragments f s y m b o l S normal-: s y m b o l T fragments normal-( subscript f 1 s y m b o l S normal-: s y m b o l T normal-) subscript f 2 fragments normal-( s y m b o l S normal-) subscript f 1 fragments normal-( s y m b o l S normal-) fragments normal-( subscript f 2 s y m b o l S normal-: s y m b o l T normal-) \frac{\partial f}{\partial symbol{S}}:symbol{T}=\left(\frac{\partial f_{1}}{% \partial symbol{S}}:symbol{T}\right)~{}f_{2}(symbol{S})+f_{1}(symbol{S})~{}% \left(\frac{\partial f_{2}}{\partial symbol{S}}:symbol{T}\right)
3) If f ( s y m b o l S ) = f 1 ( f 2 ( s y m b o l S ) ) f s y m b o l S subscript f 1 subscript f 2 s y m b o l S f(symbol{S})=f_{1}(f_{2}(symbol{S})) then ‚àÇ f ‚àÇ s y m b o l S : s y m b o l T = ‚àÇ f 1 ‚àÇ f 2 ( ‚àÇ f 2 ‚àÇ s y m b o l S : s y m b o l T ) fragments f s y m b o l S normal-: s y m b o l T subscript f 1 subscript f 2 fragments normal-( subscript f 2 s y m b o l S normal-: s y m b o l T normal-) \frac{\partial f}{\partial symbol{S}}:symbol{T}=\frac{\partial f_{1}}{\partial f% _{2}}~{}\left(\frac{\partial f_{2}}{\partial symbol{S}}:symbol{T}\right)

Derivatives of tensor valued functions of second-order tensors

Let s y m b o l F ( s y m b o l S ) s y m b o l F s y m b o l S symbol{F}(symbol{S}) be a second order tensor valued function of the second order tensor s y m b o l S s y m b o l S symbol{S} . Then the derivative of s y m b o l F ( s y m b o l S ) s y m b o l F s y m b o l S symbol{F}(symbol{S}) with respect to s y m b o l S s y m b o l S symbol{S} (or at s y m b o l S s y m b o l S symbol{S} ) in the direction s y m b o l T s y m b o l T symbol{T} is the ' fourth order tensor' defined as

‚àÇ s y m b o l F ‚àÇ s y m b o l S : s y m b o l T = D s y m b o l F ( s y m b o l S ) [ s y m b o l T ] = [ d d Œ± s y m b o l F ( s y m b o l S + Œ± s y m b o l T ) ] Œ± = 0 normal-: s y m b o l F s y m b o l S s y m b o l T D s y m b o l F s y m b o l S delimited-[] s y m b o l T subscript delimited-[] d d Œ± s y m b o l F s y m b o l S Œ± s y m b o l T Œ± 0 \frac{\partial symbol{F}}{\partial symbol{S}}:symbol{T}=Dsymbol{F}(symbol{S})[% symbol{T}]=\left[\frac{d}{d\alpha}~{}symbol{F}(symbol{S}+\alpha~{}symbol{T})% \right]_{\alpha=0} for all second order tensors s y m b o l T s y m b o l T symbol{T} .

Properties:
1) If s y m b o l F ( s y m b o l S ) = s y m b o l F 1 ( s y m b o l S ) + s y m b o l F 2 ( s y m b o l S ) s y m b o l F s y m b o l S s y m b o l subscript F 1 s y m b o l S s y m b o l subscript F 2 s y m b o l S symbol{F}(symbol{S})=symbol{F}_{1}(symbol{S})+symbol{F}_{2}(symbol{S}) then ‚àÇ s y m b o l F ‚àÇ s y m b o l S : s y m b o l T = ( ‚àÇ s y m b o l F 1 ‚àÇ s y m b o l S + ‚àÇ s y m b o l F 2 ‚àÇ s y m b o l S ) : s y m b o l T normal-: s y m b o l F s y m b o l S s y m b o l T s y m b o l subscript F 1 s y m b o l S s y m b o l subscript F 2 s y m b o l S normal-: s y m b o l T \frac{\partial symbol{F}}{\partial symbol{S}}:symbol{T}=\left(\frac{\partial symbol% {F}_{1}}{\partial symbol{S}}+\frac{\partial symbol{F}_{2}}{\partial symbol{S}}% \right):symbol{T}

3) If s y m b o l F ( s y m b o l S ) = s y m b o l F 1 ( s y m b o l F 2 ( s y m b o l S ) ) s y m b o l F s y m b o l S s y m b o l subscript F 1 s y m b o l subscript F 2 s y m b o l S symbol{F}(symbol{S})=symbol{F}_{1}(symbol{F}_{2}(symbol{S})) then ‚àÇ s y m b o l F ‚àÇ s y m b o l S : s y m b o l T = ‚àÇ s y m b o l F 1 ‚àÇ s y m b o l F 2 : ( ‚àÇ s y m b o l F 2 ‚àÇ s y m b o l S : s y m b o l T ) fragments s y m b o l F s y m b o l S normal-: s y m b o l T s y m b o l subscript F 1 s y m b o l subscript F 2 normal-: fragments normal-( s y m b o l subscript F 2 s y m b o l S normal-: s y m b o l T normal-) \frac{\partial symbol{F}}{\partial symbol{S}}:symbol{T}=\frac{\partial symbol{% F}_{1}}{\partial symbol{F}_{2}}:\left(\frac{\partial symbol{F}_{2}}{\partial symbol% {S}}:symbol{T}\right)
4) If f ( s y m b o l S ) = f 1 ( s y m b o l F 2 ( s y m b o l S ) ) f s y m b o l S subscript f 1 s y m b o l subscript F 2 s y m b o l S f(symbol{S})=f_{1}(symbol{F}_{2}(symbol{S})) then ‚àÇ f ‚àÇ s y m b o l S : s y m b o l T = ‚àÇ f 1 ‚àÇ s y m b o l F 2 : ( ‚àÇ s y m b o l F 2 ‚àÇ s y m b o l S : s y m b o l T ) fragments f s y m b o l S normal-: s y m b o l T subscript f 1 s y m b o l subscript F 2 normal-: fragments normal-( s y m b o l subscript F 2 s y m b o l S normal-: s y m b o l T normal-) \frac{\partial f}{\partial symbol{S}}:symbol{T}=\frac{\partial f_{1}}{\partial symbol% {F}_{2}}:\left(\frac{\partial symbol{F}_{2}}{\partial symbol{S}}:symbol{T}\right)

Gradient of a tensor field

The gradient, s y m b o l ‚àá s y m b o l T s y m b o l normal-‚àá s y m b o l T symbol{\nabla}symbol{T} , of a tensor field s y m b o l T ( ùê± ) s y m b o l T ùê± symbol{T}(\mathbf{x}) in the direction of an arbitrary constant vector c is defined as s y m b o l ‚àá s y m b o l T ‚ãÖ ùêú = lim Œ± ‚Üí 0 d d Œ± s y m b o l T ( ùê± + Œ± ùêú ) s y m b o l normal-‚àá normal-‚ãÖ s y m b o l T ùêú subscript normal-‚Üí Œ± 0 continued-fraction d d Œ± s y m b o l T ùê± Œ± ùêú symbol{\nabla}symbol{T}\cdot\mathbf{c}=\lim_{\alpha\rightarrow 0}\quad\cfrac{d% }{d\alpha}~{}symbol{T}(\mathbf{x}+\alpha\mathbf{c}) The gradient of a tensor field of order n is a tensor field of order n+1.

Cartesian coordinates

Curvilinear coordinates

If ùê† 1 , ùê† 2 , ùê† 3 superscript ùê† 1 superscript ùê† 2 superscript ùê† 3 \mathbf{g}^{1},\mathbf{g}^{2},\mathbf{g}^{3} are the contravariant basis vectors in a curvilinear coordinate system, with coordinates of points denoted by ( Œæ 1 , Œæ 2 , Œæ 3 superscript Œæ 1 superscript Œæ 2 superscript Œæ 3 \xi^{1},\xi^{2},\xi^{3} ), then the gradient of the tensor field s y m b o l T s y m b o l T symbol{T} is given by (see 3 for a proof.)

s y m b o l ‚àá s y m b o l T = ‚àÇ s y m b o l T ‚àÇ Œæ i ‚äó ùê† i s y m b o l normal-‚àá s y m b o l T tensor-product continued-fraction s y m b o l T superscript Œæ i superscript ùê† i symbol{\nabla}symbol{T}=\cfrac{\partial{symbol{T}}}{\partial\xi^{i}}\otimes% \mathbf{g}^{i}

Divergence of a tensor field

The divergence of a tensor field s y m b o l T ( ùê± ) s y m b o l T ùê± symbol{T}(\mathbf{x}) is defined using the recursive relation

( s y m b o l ‚àá \cdotsymbol T ) ‚ãÖ ùêú = s y m b o l ‚àá ‚ãÖ ( ùêú \cdotsymbol T ) ; \qquadsymbol ‚àá ‚ãÖ ùêØ = tr ( s y m b o l ‚àá ùêØ ) formulae-sequence normal-‚ãÖ s y m b o l normal-‚àá \cdotsymbol T ùêú normal-‚ãÖ s y m b o l normal-‚àá ùêú \cdotsymbol T normal-‚ãÖ \qquadsymbol normal-‚àá ùêØ tr s y m b o l normal-‚àá ùêØ (symbol{\nabla}\cdotsymbol{T})\cdot\mathbf{c}=symbol{\nabla}\cdot(\mathbf{c}% \cdotsymbol{T})~{};\qquadsymbol{\nabla}\cdot\mathbf{v}=\,\text{tr}(symbol{% \nabla}\mathbf{v}) where c is an arbitrary constant vector and v is a vector field. If s y m b o l T s y m b o l T symbol{T} is a tensor field of order n > 1 then the divergence of the field is a tensor of order n‚àí1.

Cartesian coordinates

In a Cartesian coordinate system we have the following relations for a vector field v and a second-order tensor field s y m b o l S s y m b o l S symbol{S} .

s y m b o l ‚àá ‚ãÖ ùêØ = ‚àÇ v i ‚àÇ x i s y m b o l ‚àá \cdotsymbol S = ‚àÇ S k i ‚àÇ x k ùêû i normal-‚ãÖ s y m b o l normal-‚àá ùêØ absent continued-fraction subscript v i subscript x i s y m b o l normal-‚àá \cdotsymbol S absent continued-fraction subscript S k i subscript x k subscript ùêû i \begin{aligned}\displaystyle symbol{\nabla}\cdot\mathbf{v}&\displaystyle=% \cfrac{\partial v_{i}}{\partial x_{i}}\\ \displaystyle symbol{\nabla}\cdotsymbol{S}&\displaystyle=\cfrac{\partial S_{ki% }}{\partial x_{k}}~{}\mathbf{e}_{i}\end{aligned}

Note that last relation can be found in reference 4 under relation (1.14.13). Note also that according to the same paper in the case of the second-order tensor field, we have s y m b o l ‚àá \cdotsymbol S ‚â† div s y m b o l S = s y m b o l ‚àá \cdotsymbol S T . s y m b o l normal-‚àá \cdotsymbol S div s y m b o l S s y m b o l normal-‚àá \cdotsymbol superscript S normal-T symbol{\nabla}\cdotsymbol{S}\neq\operatorname{div}symbol{S}=symbol{\nabla}% \cdotsymbol{S}^{\mathrm{T}}.

Curl of a tensor field

The curl of an order-n > 1 tensor field s y m b o l T ( ùê± ) s y m b o l T ùê± symbol{T}(\mathbf{x}) is also defined using the recursive relation

( s y m b o l ‚àá \timessymbol T ) ‚ãÖ ùêú = s y m b o l ‚àá √ó ( ùêú \cdotsymbol T ) ; ( s y m b o l ‚àá √ó ùêØ ) ‚ãÖ ùêú = s y m b o l ‚àá ‚ãÖ ( ùêØ √ó ùêú ) formulae-sequence normal-‚ãÖ s y m b o l normal-‚àá \timessymbol T ùêú s y m b o l normal-‚àá ùêú \cdotsymbol T normal-‚ãÖ s y m b o l normal-‚àá ùêØ ùêú normal-‚ãÖ s y m b o l normal-‚àá ùêØ ùêú (symbol{\nabla}\timessymbol{T})\cdot\mathbf{c}=symbol{\nabla}\times(\mathbf{c}% \cdotsymbol{T})~{};\qquad(symbol{\nabla}\times\mathbf{v})\cdot\mathbf{c}=% symbol{\nabla}\cdot(\mathbf{v}\times\mathbf{c}) where c is an arbitrary constant vector and v is a vector field.

Curl of a first-order tensor (vector) field

ùêØ √ó ùêú = e i j k v j c k ùêû i ùêØ ùêú subscript e i j k subscript v j subscript c k subscript ùêû i \mathbf{v}\times\mathbf{c}=e_{ijk}~{}v_{j}~{}c_{k}~{}\mathbf{e}_{i} where e i j k subscript e i j k e_{ijk} is the permutation symbol. Then,

s y m b o l ‚àá √ó ùêØ = e i j k v j , i ùêû k s y m b o l normal-‚àá ùêØ subscript e i j k subscript v j i subscript ùêû k symbol{\nabla}\times\mathbf{v}=e_{ijk}~{}v_{j,i}~{}\mathbf{e}_{k}

Identities involving the curl of a tensor field

The most commonly used identity involving the curl of a tensor field, s y m b o l T s y m b o l T symbol{T} , is

s y m b o l ‚àá √ó ( s y m b o l ‚àá s y m b o l T ) = s y m b o l 0 s y m b o l normal-‚àá s y m b o l normal-‚àá s y m b o l T s y m b o l 0 symbol{\nabla}\times(symbol{\nabla}symbol{T})=symbol{0} This identity hold for tensor fields of all orders. For the important case of a second-order tensor, s y m b o l S s y m b o l S symbol{S} , this identity implies that

s y m b o l ‚àá \timessymbol S = s y m b o l 0 ‚üπ S m i , j - S m j , i = 0 formulae-sequence s y m b o l normal-‚àá \timessymbol S s y m b o l 0 subscript S m i j subscript S m j i 0 symbol{\nabla}\timessymbol{S}=symbol{0}\quad\implies\quad S_{mi,j}-S_{mj,i}=0

Derivatives of the invariants of a second-order tensor

Derivative of the second-order identity tensor

Let s y m b o l 1 s y m b o l 1 symbol{\mathit{1}} be the second order identity tensor. Then the derivative of this tensor with respect to a second order tensor s y m b o l A s y m b o l A symbol{A} is given by

‚àÇ s y m b o l 1 ‚àÇ s y m b o l A : s y m b o l T = s y m b o l ùü¢ : s y m b o l T = s y m b o l 0 normal-: s y m b o l 1 s y m b o l A s y m b o l T s y m b o l 0 normal-: s y m b o l T s y m b o l 0 \frac{\partial symbol{\mathit{1}}}{\partial symbol{A}}:symbol{T}=symbol{% \mathsf{0}}:symbol{T}=symbol{\mathit{0}} This is because s y m b o l 1 s y m b o l 1 symbol{\mathit{1}} is independent of s y m b o l A s y m b o l A symbol{A} .

Derivative of the inverse of a second-order tensor

Proof

Recall that

Integration by parts

Another important operation related to tensor derivatives in continuum mechanics is integration by parts. The formula for integration by parts can be written as

‚à´ Œ© s y m b o l F \otimessymbol ‚àá s y m b o l G d Œ© = ‚à´ Œì ùêß ‚äó ( s y m b o l F \otimessymbol G ) d Œì - ‚à´ Œ© s y m b o l G \otimessymbol ‚àá s y m b o l F d Œ© subscript normal-Œ© s y m b o l F \otimessymbol normal-‚àá s y m b o l G normal-d normal-Œ© subscript normal-Œì tensor-product ùêß s y m b o l F \otimessymbol G normal-d normal-Œì subscript normal-Œ© s y m b o l G \otimessymbol normal-‚àá s y m b o l F normal-d normal-Œ© \int_{\Omega}symbol{F}\otimessymbol{\nabla}symbol{G}\,{\rm d}\Omega=\int_{% \Gamma}\mathbf{n}\otimes(symbol{F}\otimessymbol{G})\,{\rm d}\Gamma-\int_{% \Omega}symbol{G}\otimessymbol{\nabla}symbol{F}\,{\rm d}\Omega where s y m b o l F s y m b o l F symbol{F} and s y m b o l G s y m b o l G symbol{G} are differentiable tensor fields of arbitrary order, ùêß ùêß \mathbf{n} is the unit outward normal to the domain over which the tensor fields are defined, ‚äó tensor-product \otimes represents a generalized tensor product operator, and s y m b o l ‚àá s y m b o l normal-‚àá symbol{\nabla} is a generalized gradient operator. When s y m b o l F s y m b o l F symbol{F} is equal to the identity tensor, we get the divergence theorem

We can express the formula for integration by parts in Cartesian index notation as

For the special case where the tensor product operation is a contraction of one index and the gradient operation is a divergence, and both s y m b o l F s y m b o l F symbol{F} and s y m b o l G s y m b o l G symbol{G} are second order tensors, we have

In index notation,
